pros: You learn how to become organized or atleast aim to.
cons: Management is horrible and the some of the counselors were just absolutely terrible at being decent human beings to other staff.

pros:
1. Coworkers: Innovative, intelligent, underpaid, family-like front staff team who leaned on each other when necessary (not found at every location). Counselors worked their hardest with massive caseloads (50+ patients) despite being micromanaged and overbooked.

2. Patients: Try their best to overcome severe obstacles (overdose, relapse, crises, homelessness, poverty, etc). Often understanding and just want genuine respect and support. There are lots of opportunities to build meaningful relationships with the patients since we called them multiple times a day. Helps to have a sense of humor.

3. Growth: I grew exponentially at Horizon and now know “What Not To Do” in the Human Services field. This has shaped the rest of my career.
cons:
1. Company Diversity- Completely disproportionate to the population Horizon assists. A large number of counselors (to no fault of their own) are white women fresh out of grad school with little experience. Upper management and Senior Staff consist of white women who are detached and desensitized to the needs of both the community and “lower-tier” employees. Upper management works far from any low-income location, and acts accordingly. Very high turnover rate for Black employees.

2. Workload- Impossible and relentless. The boundaries of the Administrative Assistant position expand with every turnover. Turnovers are expected, not addressed, and are usually a result of poor management and prolonged fatigue/rage. Several locations are severely understaffed. Management takes full advantage of new staff and prioritizes pride and image over staff well-being. Supervision meetings are futile, and you’ll be asked why you can’t handle an unreasonable workload, not whether the workload is even necessary. I had 150,000 emails in a year and a half. Not worth $14.10 an hour.

3. Management- Extremely suppressive, passive-aggressive, unprofessional, and narcissistic. Conflicts are not resolved unless you take it to Employee Services, which managers do not advise. Management promotes “yes men” who won’t question them. RNs are put on a pedestal, paid extravagantly, and get away with murder. For months, front staff was outwardly bullied by a counselor and an RN, to which management repeatedly responded, “We’re working on it.” I addressed it myself and was written up. Every problem is met with band-aid solutions and severe gaslighting. You are a mule in this company.

4. Benefits- Abysmal for a generally healthy person. I paid $200 a month for a $4000 deductible I didn’t need. Annual raises were put off for months “due to COVID." Finally, we received a mandatory inflation raise passed off as our performance raise. I ended up making less per paycheck when I quit than when I started.

5. Services- Low-quality despite some amazing counselors. Horizon does not understand or care for the value of Trauma-Informed Care (prioritizing patients’ safety, choice, empowerment, collaboration, intersectionality, and trust), and actively counters some of these principles, which is a huge disservice to “over 22,000 Western New Yorkers a year.” Patients must jump through hoops to discontinue services or switch counselors. Long-term medication dependency (the company's money-maker) is a first resort. Even the word "patient" is disempowering. Patients are severely enabled until they are dependent on the company. When I discussed this with my supervisor, I was told, "Enabling is just going to happen in this field." There are Human Services employers in the area who respect those they help; this is not one of them.

Overall, Horizon Health Services is a corrupt, tone-deaf, Medicaid-milking organization with a savior complex. Staff deserves better, and patients deserve better.
